intro: Peucedanum sumbul, commonly known as the Kashmir angelica, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central and South Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small white or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters and thrives in cool, temperate climates. Its seeds are often used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. The plant's aromatic foliage and delicate flowers make it a notable addition to alpine flora.
